Matter In this module you will learn about matter, atoms, bonds, compounds and subatomic particles Matter is the substance of which all material is made. Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space. We all know when something takes up space, but what exactly is mass? Mass is simply the amount of matter in an object. If you hold a brick in one hand and a feather in your other hand, can you tell which object has more mass? The brick feels heavier, and therefore the brick has more mass. Now that we understand what matter is, lets learn more about atoms and compounds. This is the substance of which all material is made This is anything that has mass and takes up space
Bonds All atoms would like to have a full outer shell of electrons, because this is when they are most stable. When atoms without full outer shells come into contact with other atoms, they want to give up or gain electrons, this is called bonding Only the very outside electrons can form bonds, these are called "valance electrons". There are two general types of bonds that atoms can form: Ionic and covalent Ionic bonding occurs when one element donates an electron (or electrons) to another so that both atoms will have a full outer shell. In covalent bonding electrons aren't donated, but shared between electrons. So for ionic bonding, electrons move completely from one atom to another, and in covalent bonding, the same electrons are used by both atoms to have a full outer shell After bonding, the atoms become more stable than before, and their energy levels become lower This happens between the valence (outer) shell of electrons of two or more atoms This is the process of sharing electrons Atoms form these to become more stable
Hydrogen It is the simplest possible atom composed of one proton in the nucleus which is orbited by a single electron. Hydrogen is the lightest of the elements and is the most abundant element in the universe. Hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas. It is also very flammable and burns with an invisible flame. It burns when it comes into contact with oxygen. The byproduct of a hydrogen and oxygen explosion is water. This is the first element in the periodic table This gas is flammable, colorless and odorless
Oxygen Oxygen is a colorless, tasteless and odorless gas. The air, and even the water we drink has oxygen. Oxygen is a very reactive element that easily forms compounds such as oxides. This element has chemical Symbol O This element is very reactive, and easily forms compounds such as oxides
Compounds A compound is a type of molecule with more than one element. Chemical compounds are formed when elements are joined by chemical bonds. These bonds are so strong that the compound behaves like a single substance. Compounds have their own properties that are unique from the elements they are made of. For example, oxygen and hydrogen are both colorless, odorless gasses, but when they combine to form one compound, water, the new compound is completely different. This is a type of molecule with one or more element. This is formed when elements are joined together by chemical bonds
Electron cloud The electron is a negatively charged particle that spins around the outside of the nucleus. Electrons spin so fast around the nucleus, scientists can never be 100% sure where they are located, therefore they are said to exist in shells Each shell can only contain a certain number of electrons: the first layer can hold two electrons, the second layer eight electrons, the third layer eighteen electrons, etc. If there are the same number of electrons and protons in an atom, then the atom is said to have a neutral charge. Electrons have a mass of about 1/2000 of a proton, therefore, we say that they do not affect the mass of the atom, however, they're charge is equally strong as that of a proton This part of the atom has a negative charge This part of the atom contains electrons that spin around the nucleus This part of the atom doesn't affect the weight of the atom
Nucleus The nucleus contains two types of smaller particles. Protons which have a positive charge and neutrons which have no charge. Protons are the reason why a nucleus has a positive charge. This is the central part of the atom This part of the atom consists of neutrons and protons This part of the atom has an overall positive charge
Atom The atom is the basic building block for all matter in the universe. Atoms are tiny and are made up of a few even smaller particles. Every atom can be thought of as a circular shape with two parts: a nucleus and electrons The nucleus is found at the center of every atom and has a positive charge. Negatively charged electrons surround the nucleus and it's these two opposite charges that hold an atom together. This is the building block of all matter in the universe
Neutrons The neutron doesn't have any charge. The number of neutrons affects the mass and the radioactivity of the atom. This subatomic particle has no charge This subatomic particle affects the mass, but not the charge of the atom
Proton The proton is a positively charged particle that is located at the center of the atom in the nucleus. Protons also affect the mass and charge of the atom, and have the same amount of mass of a neutron This subatomic particle has a positive charge Every element has this subatomic particle, found in the nucleus of the atom

Heat and thermal energy In this module you will learn about the relationship between heat and thermal energy, as well as how they relate to particles and particle motion
//new shit ---------
Temperature Heat and temperature are two words that we use interchangeably every day, but they mean very different things in science! The temperature of something depends on how fast its particles are moving. In other words, temperature is related to the kinetic energy (the energy of movement) of the particles of matter. Matter that has faster-moving particles (higher kinetic energy) has a higher temperature than matter that has slower-moving particles (lower kinetic energy). temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance. The unit for temperature is the degree Celsius. We say “average” kinetic energy because using the average kinetic energy gives a better indication of the energy of the particles. Some particles have more energy, and other have less. This is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance The unit of measurement for this is Celsius
Heat The amount of heat in an object depends on its temperature, mass, and composition. Heat is a form of energy. Therefore, heat is related to other forms of energy, such as sound energy, electrical energy, nuclear energy etc. All these types of energy have one thing in common: energy can cause matter to change. Heat (or heat energy), is the energy that is transferred from matter at a higher temperature to matter at a lower temperature. The SI unit for heat energy is the joule. Thermometers demonstrate the ability of heat to change matter. Adding heat energy to matter generally causes matter to expand—the volume increases. Removing heat energy from matter generally causes matter to contract—the volume decreases. Now that we understand heat, lets take a look at the particle theory of matter This is a form of energy, which is related to the transfer of temperature The unit of measurement for this is joule
Particle theory of matter The following are the main ideas of the particle theory of matter: All matter is made up of extremely tiny particles, which are attracted or bonded to each other. The particles of matter are always moving and vibrating. This movement involves kinetic energy. Adding heat energy to matter makes the particles move around faster and vibrate faster. Faster-moving things have more kinetic energy. So adding heat energy increases the kinetic energy of the particles. The particles also have space between them. This is empty space not filled with air. Different states of matter have different amounts of space between the particles.

Kinetic particle theory The kinetic particle theory explains the properties of the different states of matter. The particles in solids, liquids and gases have different amounts of energy. They are arranged differently and move in different ways. This theory says that different states have different amounts of energy, and this causes them to behave and move differently This theory explains the properties of the different states of matter
Solid A solid has a definite shape and volume. The shape of solid matter does not depend on the shape of the container holding it. Your desk is a solid. In a solid, the particles are close together, and do not move. They form a regular pattern, and vibrate in one location Solids can become either liquids, in a process called melting, or gasses, in a process called sublimation This state of matter has particles close together, and is unable to change shape This state of matter has particles vibrating in only one location Particles in this state cannot flow
Liquid A liquid flows, has a fixed volume, and takes the shape of its container. Ketchup, water, and melted ice cream are liquids In a liquid the particles are close together, but they can still move around each other. Liquids can become solids in a process called freezing, or a gas in a process called boiling Boiling is not to be confused with evaporation, they are different in the following ways: evaporation can occur at any temperature - not just the boiling point It only happens at the surface of the liquid - not throughout like boiling, and finally boiling requires energy, whereas evaporation is the release of the highest energy particles This state of matter has particles close together, however, they are able to change shape This state of matter can both freeze, boil and evaporate This state of matter takes the shape of the container it is in, and is unable to be compressed
Brownian motion Particles in both liquids and gases (collectively called fluids) move randomly. This is called Brownian motion. They do this because they are bombarded by the other moving particles in the fluid. Think of many ping pong balls flying and crashign into each other Brownian motion is named after the botanist Robert Brown, who first observed this in 1827. He used a microscope to look at pollen grains moving randomly in water. At this point, he could not explain why this occurred. But in 1905, physicist Albert Einstein explained that the pollen grains were being moved by individual water molecules. This confirmed that atoms and molecules did exist, and provided evidence for particle theory. This states that particles move randomly This theory helped prove that atoms and molecules exist, and provided evidence for the particle theory
Gas A gas takes the shape and volume of its container. Smoke and steam are gases. In a gas the particles are far apart, in a random arrangement, and they move quickly in all directions Gasses flow and completely fill their container, this is because the particles can quickly move in all directions, and try to spread out as much as possible Gasses can be squished and compressed, this is because there is space between the particles themselves In this state of matter, the particles are far apart and move quickly In this state of matter particles can be compressed
Thermal expansion All three states of matter (solid, liquid and gas) expand when heated. The atoms themselves do not expand, but the space between them, and therefore the volume does When a solid is heated, its atoms vibrate faster about their fixed points. The relative increase in the size of solids when heated is therefore small. Liquids expand for the same reason, but because the bonds between separate molecules are usually less tight they expand more than solids. Molecules within gases are further apart and weakly attracted to each other. Heat causes the molecules to move faster, which means that the volume of a gas increases more than the volume of a solid or liquid. This states that all states of matter expand when heated Liquid thermometers work thanks to this theory

Physical Change Physical changes happen when there is no change in the chemical formula. In other words, no chemical bonds were broken or created Some examples of physical change include changing states (such as a solid to a liquid). In general, its easy to undo physical changes (like freezing the water again) Ice melting is an example of this type of change Breaking metal in half is an example of this type of change Mixing sand and water is an example of this type of change
Chemical Change Chemical changes happen when the chemical formula becomes different. In other words, there was some chemical bond that was broken, or created. Some examples of chemical changes include burning, dissolving, and other chemical reactions. In general, its much harder to undo chemical changes. This type of change includes a change in composition Propane burning is an example of this type of change Metal rusting is an example of this type of change Dissolving salt in water is an example of this type of change
Chemical bonds Chemical bonds are forces that hold atoms together in a single molecule. Some examples of chemical bonds include ionic bonds, and covalent bonds. These bonds are very strong, and are difficult to break. This is what holds atoms together in a molecule These types of bonds are strong, and difficult to break
Intermolecular bonds Intermolecular bonds are forces that hold molecules together. All molecules have some form of intermolecular forces, although they may be very weak. These types of bonds act between molecules, and are relatively weak
Forming mixtures One of the main aspects of chemistry is combining different substances. Sometimes combining substances can cause a chemical reaction and bonding which creates an entirely new substance called a compound. However, sometimes there is no chemical reaction or bonding. In this case, a mixture is formed from the combined substances.
Mixtures A mixture is made when two or more substances are combined, but they are not combined chemically. A pure substance, such as table salt, is made up of just one type of particle. A mixture, such as soil, is made up of more than one type of particle. General properties of a mixture: The components of a mixture can be easily separated, the components each keep their original properties, the proportion of the components is variable
Types of mixtures There are two main categories of mixtures: homogeneous mixtures and heterogeneous mixtures. In a homogeneous mixture all the substances are evenly distributed throughout the mixture (salt water, air, blood). In a heterogeneous mixture the substances are not evenly distributed (chocolate chip cookies, pizza, rocks) Within the categories of homogeneous and heterogeneous mixtures there are more specific types of mixtures including solutions, alloys, suspensions, and colloids.
//these ones show up when you change the dropdown Solutions A solution is a mixture where one of the substances dissolves in the other. The substance that dissolves is called the solute. The substance that does not dissolve is called the solvent. The amount of a solvent that we can dissolve is determined by the solubility. If you started to add sugar to water, you would notice that after a certain amount, it would stop dissolving, this amount is called the solubility Not all solutes and solvents form solutions. For example, if you added sand to water, it would not dissolve Some solutes “fit” with the solvent and dissolve. For example, sugar dissolves in water because the sugar particles bind (combine) with the water particles. Some solute particles do not bind with the solvent particles. Solutes that do not bind well are called insoluble solutes. Sometimes, it's possible to dissolve more of a solvent than normal, these solutions are called "super-saturated" Once a solution is formed, there are ways to separate solutions. these include filtration, distillation and decanting let's take a look at these below Filtration is a common technique used to separate solids from liquids. A common example used in many household kitchens is making coffee. The coffee grounds are in a coffee filter. Water drips onto the coffee grounds, absorbs the soluble coffee, and drips through the filter. The insoluble grounds are left behind because they cannot pass through the filter. Some solutions are made up of more than one solvent. In these solutions, a process called distillation can be used to separate a solid from a liquid or one liquid in a mixture from another. Decanting is a technique used to separate a liquid from a denser solid or liquid that is insoluble in water. This is a type of mixture where one substance dissolves the other It consists of two parts, the solute and the solvent Salt water is this type of mixture
Alloys An alloy is a mixture of elements that has the characteristic of a metal. At least one of the elements mixed is a metal. One example of an alloy is steel which is made from a mixture of iron and carbon. This is a mixture of elements that have the characteristics of a metal At least one of the elements in these mixtures is a metal Steel is an example of this alloy
Bronze Bronze is a metal alloy. Bronze is mostly copper, with some tin added (usually between 5% and 20% tin). Bronze was the first alloy that was used by humans. The first nation that used Bronze was Egypt about 3500 years B.C. This gave the name for the Bronze Age. Bronze is stronger than copper or tin alone. Bronze lasts longer than copper. Pure copper can be oxidized by air and also by water. When copper is oxidized by air or water, it turns green (the color of "copper oxide"), and falls apart. This was the first alloy used by humans This alloy is made of copper and tin
Steal Steel is a mixture of several metals but most of it is iron. Steel is harder and stronger than iron. Steels are often iron alloys with between 0.02% and 1.7% percent carbon by weight. Steel has a long history. People in India and Sri Lanka were making small amounts of steel more than 2,500 years ago. It was very expensive and was often used to make swords and knives. It is a very cheap metal and is used to make many things. Steel is used in making buildings and bridges, and all kinds of machines. Almost all ships and cars are today made from steel. When a steel object is old, or it is broken beyond repair, it is called scrap. It can be melted down and re-shaped into a new object. Steel is recyclable material; that is, the same steel can be used and re-used. This is one of the most common alloys in use today, and is used in machines, building, and cars among other things This alloy is made of iron and carbon
Solder Solder is a metal or alloy that melts at a low temperature. Here are two types of solder; soft solder and hard solder. Soft solder melts easily with soldering irons and is used for electronics and electrical work. Hard solder melts at a higher temperature with a torch. There are two main types of soft solder; lead solder and lead-free solder. Lead solders have about 60% (or 63%) tin and 40% (or 37%) lead in them. Today lead solder is banned in many applications, because of its toxic effects This alloy melts at very low temperatures This alloy is made of tin and lead
Suspensions A suspension is a mixture between a liquid and particles of a solid. In this case the particles do not dissolve. The particles and the liquid are mixed up so that the particles are dispersed throughout the liquid. They are "suspended" in the liquid. A key characteristic of a suspension is that the solid particles will settle and separate over time if left alone. An example of a suspension is a mixture of water and sand. When mixed up, the sand will disperse throughout the water. If left alone, the sand will settle to the bottom. If I mix water and sand, it becomes this kind of mixture
Colloids A colloid is a mixture where very small particles of one substance are evenly distributed throughout another substance. They appear very similar to solutions, but the particles are suspended in the solution rather than fully dissolved. The difference between a colloid and a suspension is that the particles will not settle to the bottom over a period of time, they will stay suspended or float. This type of mixtures is similar to suspensions, but the particles do not settle over time This type of mixture has particles suspended and spread out in the solution
Concentration In chemistry, concentration is how much of a substance is mixed with another substance. In other words, it has many solute particles compared with the number of solvent particles. The substance that is dissolved (shown as the red dye in the example) is known as the solute. The substance in which the solute is dissolved (shown as the water in the example) is known as the solvent. To concentrate a solution, one must add more solute, or reduce the amount of solvent. To dilute a solution, one must add more solvent, or reduce the amount of solute. A dilute solution has small amounts of solute in a solvent, or has only a few solute particles compared with the number of solvent particles. Concentrated and dilute are relative terms. They tell you whether there are small or large amounts of solute in the solvent. But they do not tell you exactly how much solute is in a certain amount of solvent. The concentration of a solution tells you the amount of solute (in grams) dissolved in a certain amount of solution. For example, a solution with 50 g of solute dissolved in 100 mL of water is said to have a concentration of 50 g/100 mL of solution. This is read as “fifty grams per one hundred milliliters.” This describes the amount of a substance (the solute) that is dissolved in another substance (the solvent) This describes how dilute, or how concentrated a solution is

Plants In this module you will learn about the different parts of plants and flowers Plants are one of the few living things that can make their own food. This makes them an important source of food for other living things.
Seeds Seeds come in many shapes and sizes. New plants often grow from seeds. Before seeds grow into plants, they must germinate, or sprout This is how all plants begin their lives This part of the plant germinates, or sprouts
Flowers The flowers of a plant contain parts to produce seeds. The flowers produce fruits with seeds inside. Flowers produce a sweet liquid called nectar. Nectar is food for insects. Flowers also produce a special powder called pollen. Pollen is produced in a part of the flower called the stamen. Insects such as bees are attracted to the flower by the nectar. Pollen from the flower sticks to them. Later, the insect moves on to another flower. The pollen stuck on the insect brushes off onto a different part of this flower. This part is called the pistil. This process is called pollination Flowers need to be pollinated to make seeds. This part of the plant contains the parts that produce seeds This part of the plant produces nectar and pollen
Leaves Most leaves are green. This is because leaves have a very special green substance in them. Scientists call this substance chlorophyll. It can trap energy from sunlight to make food for the plant. this part of the plant contains chlorophyll This part of the plant produced the food for the plant
Stem The stem (or trunk) of a plant holds the plant up. It carries water and nutrients from the roots to the leaves. Sometimes stems can store food. This is what holds the plant up This part of the plant carries nutrients from its roots to its leaves, and sometimes stores food
Roots Roots hold the plant in the ground. They absorb water and nutrients. Some roots can store food for the plant. This is what holds the plant in the ground This part of the plant absorbs water and nutrients, and can sometimes store food for the plant
Water All plants need water to survive. Plants need water to keep their shape, turn sunlight into energy, and take in nutrients from soil. Plants also use water to carry nutrients from their roots to their leaves. Plants also give off water through their leaves to cool off in hot weather. For plants, maybe photosynthesis. Since plants use water for so many things, they need a way to get a lot of water easily. Water is in the air and in the ground. The roots of plants take in water from the ground. The stems of plants then carry water from the roots to the leaves. In fact, you have seen that the stem of a celery leaf is like a highway for transporting water. This liquid is needed by all plants to survive This substance helps plants keep their shape, turn sunlight into food, and take nutrients from the soil Plants use this to cool off in hot weather
//you need to group these ----------
Soil In addition to water, plants also need soil to grow, and get nutrients Scientists talk about soil being made up of four non-living parts—rocks, air, water, and humus. When plants or animals die, they begin to decompose in the ground. These rotted plants and animals in soil are called humus. Humus is very dark brown. It crumbles when you touch it. Humus mixes with tiny particles of rocks, air, and water to form soil. Scientists call the three main kinds of rock particles in soil sand, silt, and clay. Sand particles are the largest. They feel gritty. Silt particles are not as big as sand. They feel like powder. Clay particles are the smallest. They feel smooth and are sticky when wet. Plants need this to grow and get nutrients. It is made up of four non-living parts

Energy Sources In this module, you will learn about the different ways we generate electricity today There are two types of energy sources, renewable and non-renewable. As we begin to need and depend more on energy, it is more important than ever to understand each of the different sources. As well as their pros and cons. A renewable energy resource can be used over and over. It is never used up. energy resource can only be used once. This is because most non-renewable energy resources are fossil fuels made from the organic remains of plants and animals. Fossil fuels take millions of years to form and therefore cannot be quickly replaced.
Nuclear power Nuclear power is the controlled use of nuclear energy. Nuclear energy is energy in uranium that can be released by nuclear reactions in a machine called a nuclear reactor. This energy is made into electricity, which then can be used to power machines and heat homes. 14% of the world's electricity came from nuclear power. Nuclear power plants also make radioactive waste that could be harmful if it is not stored properly. Nuclear power plants produce less radioactive material than a coal-fired power station Nuclear power plants operate on a process known as fission, which takes a larger molecule and breaks it into smaller pieces, releasing energy in the process The sun uses a process known as nuclear fusion, which joins two smaller molecules together to form a larger one, releasing a huge amount of heat. Researchers hope to use this form of energy in the future, as it is safer, more efficient, and greener than any current technology
There are several things to consider nuclear energy. Nuclear power plants are expensive to build and maintain. A nuclear power plant functions for 30 to 50 years before it must be decommissioned. The waste is highly radioactive and must be carefully handled and stored for a long period of time. Chances of a nuclear accident must be minimized.
It generates energy from radioactive materials This power source operates on a process known as nuclear fission This power source has caused many disasters, such as Chernobyl, or Three Mile Island
Hydro power
Hydroelectricity is electricity generated by the force of water. Hydroelectric generating stations create electricity by having a flow of water turn a generator. A spinning generator changes the energy of its motion into electrical energy. Water needed to spin the generator usually comes from a river that has been blocked by a dam. The blocked water forms a reservoir that can be used for both recreational activities and farm irrigation. With a dam, there will always be water available to turn the generators and make electricity. Dams are expensive to build and so are the long transmission lines that carry electricity from the dams to businesses and homes. However, hydroelectric power generators run without creating pollution, and they are reasonably cheap to operate. Unlike other energy resources, hydroelectric power generators can be started and stopped in a matter of minutes. This makes them more flexible to use during high demand times. There are only a limited number of places where hydroelectric dams can be built because of impacts on the environment and local communities. When a dam and reservoir are created, flooding of the surrounding land affects the habitat of all plant and animal life in the area.
This form of power uses the flowing of water to generate electricity This power source can cause flooding in some areas, and can damage the ecosystem
Oil and Coal power Almost half of the world’s electricity comes from burning coal. Coal is burned to heat water into steam, which is then used to spin generators to create electricity. The process is similar to the generators in dams, except that in dams water is used instead of steam. Using coal for making electricity is relatively cheap, and the world has a large quantity of coal available. An added benefit of using coal is that other products can be made from it. These products include fertilizers, paints, and plastics. However, using coal has disadvantages. Mining coal can be dangerous and disruptive to the environment, so mining companies are required to try to restore the land to its original form when they have completed the mining process. Burning coal can create air and water pollution and is often considered one of the “dirtiest” forms of energy generation. As coal is non-renewable, it will eventually be used up, or be too expensive to mine.
This is our main form of generating electricity currently, however it is harmful to the environment This power source uses organic material that is millions of years old
Wind power Wind energy is the energy from the bulk movement of air. Wind is caused by pressure differences in the atmosphere which are caused by uneven heating of the earth by the sun. Air moves from areas of higher pressure to areas of lower pressure, which produces wind as a result. Wind power is the fastest growing renewable energy source. It is also the most widely available renewable energy source in the world.
Collecting energy from the wind requires a windmill, turbine, or blade to catch and turn in the wind. There are many types of devices that can be used but the multi blade and two- or three-blade high-speed rotors are the most common. Wind is free, renewable, and emission free, and windmills can be set up faster than dams or coal power plants. Unfortunately, wind speed is variable, turbines break down, birds can be killed flying into them, and the electricity is expensive to generate. Also, a large area of land is needed for “wind farms.” the long-term effects of wind farms on the land are not known. There is the possibility of noise pollution from the sound of the blades for those living close by.
This is the fastest growing renewable energy source This energy source uses the movement of air to create electricity This energy source can be over 100 meters tall This energy source is often found near oceans, or fields
Solar power Solar energy is the energy that is in sunlight. Solar power plants convert sunlight into electricity, either directly using photovoltaics (PV), or indirectly using concentrated solar power (CSP). concentrated solar power systems use lenses or mirrors and tracking systems to focus a large area of sunlight into a small beam. Photovoltaic converts light into electric current using the photoelectric effect.
The collection and use of the free heat energy from the Sun for household heating is called passive solar heating. When solar energy is used in conjunction with other electrical devices, it is called active solar heating. Solar energy is simple to use. It can be added to houses quite easily. There is generally no visible pollution when solar energy is used to generate electricity. However, using solar energy to generate electricity does have some problems. The Sun only shines for part of the day, and some days may be cloudy. A solar cell used to generate electricity is quite expensive. Generating electricity from solar energy also takes up a lot of space. Many generating projects using solar energy are small-scale because it would take a large area of land to produce a vast amount of electricity.
This form of energy uses the technology of photovoltaics, or concentrated solar power, to generate electricity This form of energy can only produce electricity during the day
//new mdoel
Biomass Biomass is any plant or animal material that can be safely burned and makes a good fuel. Most organic material, trees and shrubs, and most agricultural material, for example, grains or crops, can be used as biomass. Even animal manure is used. Biomass energy generation reuses organic material to produce energy. Biomass is burned to create steam in electricity generators similar to those fueled by wind and geothermal energy. Reusing these wastes has great potential not only as an efficient energy source, but also as a positive impact on the environment. Landfills and waste centers could be used less, and the supply of waste never runs out! The supply of biomass would be cheap, but the cost of building a new generation unit is very expensive. Also, people need to be careful about what is used as biomass. Some waste products, like plastic, should not be burned. Because biomass use is relatively new, there are not many rules on how much, or what, should be burned. Many people are concerned that if burning biomass is not properly regulated, companies might start burning materials that are not considered “waste.”
This is the use of animal or plant remains for energy This is a relatively new form of energy, and there are not many rules, which could lead to environmental problems This power source not only creates energy, but also decreases waste

Fossils In this module you will learn about fossils, how they are formed, how they are found, and why they are important Fossils can be the shells, bones, or teeth of animals. They can be the leaves, pollen, or woody stems of plants. Fossils can even be the bones or teeth of ancient people. In other words, a fossil is the remains, imprint, or trace of a plant or animal that lived long ago. Fossils are found in sedimentary rock, such as limestone, sandstone, or shale. there are many types of fossils, let's explore them!
Why are fossils important? Their observations can sometimes tell scientists what might have happened on Earth during the time that the fossilized plant or animal lived. fossils help scientists understand the events of the past, how organisms looked, and how they lived. By studying fossils we can determine what an organism looked like. Fossils can also tell us about the gradual changes and adaptations that a species underwent. By examining a collection of fossils in an area, scientists may be able to explain why certain animals became extinct. This information may help us to prevent events like this from happening again, or at the very least present us with warning signs.
Types of fossils There are many types of fossils, lets explore them!
trace fossil An impression of a footprint or burrow found in a rock. These impressions are not actual remains of an animal or a plant, but they still teach us a lot about ancient life.
mold fossil An empty space in a rock, where a whole plant or animal has Decayed
cast fossil Minerals and sediment that have seeped through a rock and hardened to form the shape of the fossil mold
petrified fossil Bone or shell material is replaced by minerals
Paleontologists Scientists who study fossils are called paleontologists. Often, paleontologists find fossils that are only pieces of plants and animals. They may not find all the pieces. Their job is like putting together a jigsaw puzzle with missing pieces, and there is no picture of how the completed puzzle should look! Paleontologists take special care when bringing fossils back to a laboratory, where they test, measure, and study them to figure out their age.
Coelophysis Coelophysis is a small dinosaur that lived approximately 200 million years ago in the Late Triassic Period. It is named Coelophysis—which means “hollow form”–because this dinosaur had hollow bones. This dinosaur was about 9 feet long, 3 feet high and weighed about 100 pounds at most. It’s hollow bone structure made it light and agile, This dinosaur lived about 200 million years ago, and had hollow bones
Giant ground sloth Giant ground sloths were large, lumbering beasts that lived in the Americas during the Ice Age. They were directly related to today's modern sloths. They were also distantly related to anteaters and armadillos. By the end of the Great Ice Age, around 11,700 years ago, many believe that the giant ground sloths had become extinct. Some argue that they were around for many more thousands of years, though, surviving on islands in the Caribbean. This animal lived during the Ice Age, and are related to today's sloths
Mammoth Mammoths were hairy elephants of the genus Mammuthus. They lived in Europe until 4,500 years ago, and were adapted to cold climate. They were killed off by hunters and climate change. Like their modern relatives, mammoths were quite large. The largest known species reached heights in the region of 4 m at the shoulder and weights of up to 8 tonnes, while exceptionally large males may have exceeded 12 tonnes. Their diet was mainly grazing, these assumptions were based on mammoth feces and mammoth teeth, such as the molar shown here European mammoths had a major diet of C3 carbon fixation plants. This was determined by examining the isotopic data from the European mammoth teeth. These animals looked like hairy elephants These animals were killed off by hunters and climate change 4,500 years ago From fossils of this animals teeth, they found out it had a major diet of plants
Short faced bear The short-faced bear or bulldog bear (Arctodus) is an extinct genus of bear endemic to North America during the Pleistocene era about 1.8 million years ago (mya) to 11,000 years ago. At that time it may have been one of the largest mammals that lived on land and ate meat. The short-faced bear lived in many parts of North America, ranging from Alaska to Mississippi. However, it lived mostly in southern areas, from northern Texas to New Jersey in the east; Aguascalientes, Mexico to the southwest; and with large concentrations in Florida. The short face bear found was estimated to be largest was 957 kg. When it was standing on its hind (back) legs, the bear was 2.4–3.0 m tall. This animal lived during the Ice Age, and was the largest land carnivore at the time
Spinosaurus Spinosaurus (which means 'spiny lizard') was a huge semi-aquatic dinosaur from the Cretaceous, 112 to 97 million years ago. It had paddle-like feet and nostrils on top of its crocodile-like head. Estimates suggest that it was 12.6 to 18 meters in length and 7 to 20.9 tonnes in weight. It lived in what is now Sahara Desert, but which then was mangrove forests alongside shoreline conditions, tidal flats and channels. Spinosaurus is known to have eaten fish. Evidence suggests that it lived both on land and in water like a modern crocodilian. This dinosaur is related to todays crocodile
Trilobite Trilobite (meaning "three lobed") are extinct arthropods. Their name is in reference to the three round parts, called lobes, across their heads Trilobites appeared some 600 million years ago during the Cambrian period. They belonged to the phylum Arthropoda (joint-footed), a phylum which to this day represents the most successful (78%) of all animal life forms, including crabs, centipedes, spiders, shrimps and insects. Trilobites are the earliest known animal to have vision. Some possessed eyes and some seem to have no eyes at all, while others had eyes made up of many parts that could see all around the animal. Trilobites ranged in length from 1 millimetre to 72 centimetres, with a typical size range of 3–10 cm (1.2–3.9 in). These animals were one of the first to have eyes

Flight In this module you will learn about how flying works, and the different ways we fly today Before we learn about flight, lets review a little about forces
Forces For scientists, a force causes an object’s motion to change. It can be a push or a pull.
Gravity and Lift Gravity is the force of attraction between two objects that have mass. For example, you are pulled toward Earth, and Earth is pulled toward you. Scientists call this pull gravity. They have found that the more mass an object has, the greater the force of gravity between Earth and that object
Living things that fly must experience a force that goes against gravity. Scientists call such a force lift. For something to fly there must be enough lift to overcome the force of gravity. Naturally, birds require less lift to fly than airplanes. The lighter the object, the less lift required.
This is the force that goes against gravity In order to fly, this force must be equal to or greater than gravity
this is the force of attraction between two objects that have mass All objects must overcome this force in order to fly
Thrust and Drag Thrust is the scientific name of the force that pushes any animal or object forward. Birds and insects get their thrust and lift from flapping their wings.
Drag is the scientific name of a force that slows you down. Drag resists motion. As birds and insects move through the air, the air pushes against their movement, creating drag.
This is a force that slows you down This force is caused by air pushing against the movement of an object
This forces pushes an object or animal forward
Internal combustion engines Early airplanes used an internal combustion engine, an engine in which the fuel is burned within the engine itself. This engine powered the propeller, which provided thrust. This was used in early airplanes This is what powered the propeller in early airplanes
Jet Engines Henri Coanda’s first jet engine created thrust differently. Jet engines work by igniting fuel and compressed oxygen inside the engine. This causes a large amount of exhaust gas to be released out of the rear of the aircraft, creating a large force. This force propels the aircraft forward. This engine was invented by Henri Coanda This engine ignites fuel and compressed oxygen
Rocket Rocket engines have been used to create thrust in rockets, airplanes, and spacecraft. All rocket engines accelerate a fluid for this purpose. In a chemical rocket engine, a fuel is burned, creating exhaust gases. High pressures and temperatures help to push the exhaust gases through a narrow rocket nozzle. Earlier, you learned that if the width of a passageway is narrowed, a fluid will move through it more quickly. This causes the exhaust gases to accelerate as they pass through the rocket nozzle, and thrust is created. This engine uses a narrow nozzle to propel the exhaust gasses out, and create thrust

Photosynthesis In this module, you will learn about the chemical process called photosynthesis, which allows plants to produce energy from the sun, carbon dioxide, and water.
Carbon Dioxide Carbon dioxide is a gas that is present in the air. Plants collect carbon dioxide through tiny holes called stomates. Carbon dioxide is then combined with water and oxygen in a process known as photosynthesis This gas is needed to complete photosynthesis
Energy from the Sun Sunlight is absorbed by a green chemical in the leaves, called chlorophyll The energy from the sun is used to split the water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen This source of energy is required for photosynthesis This is what splits water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen
Oxygen During the process of photosynthesis, stomates are used to expel a gas called oxygen. Oxygen is very important for animals like humans – we need it to breathe! This is byproduct of photosynthesis is expelled by the plant
Glucose Glucose is a type of sugar, that the plant uses as energy to grow, and reproduce Glucose is produced through photosynthesis, the word equation would be: Carbon Dioxide + Water + Light Energy = Glucose + Oxygen This is what the plant produces through photosynthesis, which it uses to grow and reproduce

Simple machines In this module you will learn about simple machines, and forces. As well as some everyday examples where they are used! Simple machines help us apply force. Lifting a load, which is a weight to be carried or moved, is an example of applying force. Some simple machines create a mechanical advantage to help you use less force to lift a load. A mechanical advantage is when you apply less force to lift a load than you would without the simple machine. Simple machines can also change the direction in which a force needs to be applied, or the speed in which a load moves. Before we learn about simple machines, lets learn a little about forces These help use apply a force, or create a mechanical advantage
Forces In science, a force is a push or a pull that causes an object to start or stop moving, or changes the direction an object is moving. Sir Isaac Newton was a scientist who lived over 300 years ago. He discovered that forces occur in pairs, and they can be either balanced or unbalanced. How do we know if forces are balanced or unbalanced? When an object travels at a constant speed, Newton concluded that the forces acting on the object are balanced. This is something that changes an objects motion
lever A lever is a rigid rod that rotates at a point anywhere along the lever. This point is called the fulcrum. There are different classes of levers. These different classes of levers have different effects on the loads they move. A lever might be able to decrease the effort force required to move a load change the direction that a load moves increase the distance that a load moves increase the speed with which a load moves This simple machine has three classes, that have different effects on the loads they move This simple machine is a rigid rod that rotates around a fulcrum
First class lever A see-saw is a first class lever. In a first class lever, the fulcrum is between the effort and the load. A first class lever always changes the direction of the force. If a force is applied downward, the load moves upward. This simple machine has the fulcrum between the effort and the load, and always changes the direction of the force a see-saw is an example of this simple machine
Second class lever A wheelbarrow is a second class lever. In a second class lever, the load is between the fulcrum and the effort. A second class lever never changes the direction of the force. If a force is applied upward, the load moves upward. The closer the load is to the fulcrum, the less force is required to move the load. A wheelbarrow is an example of this simple machine In this simple machine the load is in between the fulcrum and the effort
Third class lever A hoe is a third class lever. In a third class lever, the effort is between the fulcrum and the load. A third class lever never changes the direction of the force. A third class lever also does not change the amount of force required to move the load. We use third class levers because they increase the speed of the load. A hoe is an example of this simple machine This simple machine never changes the direction of the force, and it does not change the amount of force required to move the load
wheel and axle A wheel and axle consists of a large wheel connected to a small wheel through its center. The small wheel is called the axle. When one wheel turns, so does the other. This simple machine consists of a large wheel connected to a small wheel through its center
pulley system A pulley system includes one or more grooved wheels with a rope running through the groove. The wheel is attached to something that does not move. Pulleys are usually used in sets designed to make the amount of force needed to lift something smaller. This simple machine includes one or more grooved wheels with a rope
inclined plane An inclined plane is a sloped surface or ramp. Examples of inclined planes are ramps, sloping roads and hills, plows, chisels, hatchets, carpenter's planes, and wedges. The typical example of an inclined plane is a sloped surface; for example a roadway to bridge a height difference. Examples of this simple machine include plows, chisels and wedges Examples of this simple machine include roadways or bridges with a height difference

Microscopes In this module you will learn about the different types, and different parts in a microscope First, what is a microscope? Microscopes allow us to see extremely small "microscopic" things First, lets take a look at the different types of microscopes
Types of microscopes Any microscope that has two or more lenses is called a compound microscope. When you view an object with a microscope, you need light to see the structures. Because light must travel through the object for you to see it properly, you will see a lamp or other light source under the microscope’s stage. That’s why the full name for your microscope is compound light microscope.
Eye piece acts like a magnifying glass This part of the microscope acts as a magnifying glass
Body tube connects the eyepiece and the revolving nose-piece This part of the microscope contains the eyepiece and revolving nose piece
Coarse adjustment Knob brings the lens closer to or farther from the object to produce a clear, sharp image This part of the microscope brings the lens closer or farther from the object
Evolving Nose-piece holds the three objective lenses This part of the microscope holds three objective lenses
Objective Lenses provide different strengths (powers) of magnification This part of the microscope provides different strengths of magnification
Stage place where you put the slide that holds the object you want to view This is where you put the slide that holds the object you want to view
Stage clips Used to hold the object on the stage This is used to hold the object on the stage
Diaphragm has different-sized holes or a lever that moves to let different amounts of light pass through This part of the microscope lets different amounts of light pass through
Lamp directs light through the object you are viewing This part of the microscope directs light through the object you are viewing
Arm houses the adjustment knobs and helps you carry the microscope securely This part of the microscope houses the adjustment knobs
Base serves as a foundation for the rest of the microscope This part of the microscope serves as the foundation for the rest of the microscope

Animal Cells In this module you will learn about the structure and parts of an animal cell, as well as some information about cell theory and organisms
//new -------------
Cell Theory The Cell Theory states the following All living things are composed of cells Cells are the basic units of structure and function in living things. All cells are produced from other cells.
Organisms Some organisms are multicellular. This means that they are made up of two or more cells. Plants and animals are examples of multicellular organisms. Other organisms are unicellular. They are made up of only a single cell. Most microscopic organisms are examples of unicellular organisms.
Organelles The inside of the cell contains a liquid-like substance called the cytoplasm. In those cells that have a nucleus, the cytoplasm contains a variety of structures, which carry out particular functions or jobs. These structures are called organelles and each has a recognizable shape.
//new
Nucleus The nucleus is small and round, and it works as the cell's control center. It contains chromosomes which house the DNA. The human body contains billions of cells, most of which have a nucleus. Inside the nucleus there are no membrane-bound sub-compartments. Its contents are not uniform, and a number of sub-nuclear bodies exist, made up of unique proteins, RNA molecules, and particular parts of the chromosomes. The nucleus is surrounded by a nuclear membrane. Large molecules cannot get through the double-layer nuclear membrane: it is impermeable to them. However, nuclear pores exist. They control the movement of molecules across the membrane. This contains the cells DNA This organelle is small and round, and contains chromosomes This organelle has a membrane, which larger molecules cannot cross
Ribosomes Ribosomes are important cell organelles. A ribosome is a large complex of RNA and protein. It does RNA translation, building proteins from amino acids using messenger RNA as a template. Ribosomes are found in all living cells The job of the ribosome is to make new proteins. It does this by moving along a strand of RNA and building a protein based on the code it reads. Making a protein this way is called translation. Ribosomes are usually found in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, but can also be found throughout the cytoplasm. This organelle is found in every cell, and is responsible for making proteins This organelle is mainly found in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, but can be found in the cytoplasm as well This organelle translates RNA to create new proteins
Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a cellular organelle. It is the transport network for molecules going to specific places, as compared to molecules that float freely in the cytoplasm. Among its functions is the production of proteins and steroids, the maintenance of plasma membranes, and a pathway for molecules to move along. It contains enzymes, proteins and lipids This organelle contains enzymes, proteins and lipids This organelle serves as a transport network This organelle is responsible for the production of proteins, steroids and the maintenance of plasma membranes
Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), so called because it is studded with ribosomes, and secretes proteins into the cytoplasm. Ribosomes are the location of protein synthesis, or where proteins used in the cell are put together This organelle is covered in ribosomes This organelle secretes proteins into the cytoplasm
LysosomeA lysosome is a cell organelle. They are like spheres. They have hydrolytic enzymes which can break down almost all kinds of biomolecules, including proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, lipids, and cellular debrisLysosomes work like the digestive system to break down, or digest, proteins, acids, carbohydrates, dead organelles, and other unwanted materials. They break up larger molecules into smaller molecules. Those smaller molecules can then be used again as building blocks for other large molecules. // Lysosomes are the proteins or carbohydrates released from the Golgi body // Lysosomes connect to the cell membrane and releases their contents from inside their sac to outside the cell. // It releases its contents to outside the cellThese organelles are shaped like sphere's, and contain enzymes that break down most kinds of biomoleculesThese organelles recycle larger molecules to be reusedThis organelles are similar to a digestive system, and digest proteins, acids, carbohydrates and dead or unwanted materials
Golgi BodyThe Golgi complex, also known as the Golgi apparatus or simply the Golgi, is a cytoplasmic organelle.The main function of the Golgi apparatus is to process and package macromolecules, such as proteins and lipids. They come to the Golgi after being built, and before they go to their destination.The Golgi complex inspects them for flaws and discards extra material added during their manufacture, wraps them up and then targets them for packaging. The Golgi releases special enzymes called lysosomes, which clean off any extra amino acids. When the package is ready, it is pinched off the Golgi and released into the cytoplasm.
// The Golgi body is a sac-like body that packages proteins and carbohydrates into membrane-covered sacs for export from the cellThis organelle processes and packages macromoleculesThis organelle inspects macromolecules for flaws, before packaging them and sending them to their targetsThis organelle releases lysosomes
Mitochondrion The mitochondria are the power houses of the cell. They make most of the cell's supply of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), a molecule that cells use as a source of energy. Their main job is this energy conversion. They oxidize glucose to provide energy for the cell. The process makes ATP, and is called cellular respiration. In addition to supplying cellular energy, mitochondria are involved in a range of other processes, such as signalling, cellular differentiation, cell death, as well as the control of the cell division cycle and cell growth. It is thought that mitochondria were once independent bacteria, and became part of the eukaryotic cells by being engulfed, a process called endosymbiosis. This organelle supplies the cell with energy This organelle supplies the cell with a chemical called ATP This organelle is thought to have once been a separate bacteria
Vacuoles Vacuoles are organelles that are filled with fluid and remove waste products from the cell Vacuoles are also digestive and help break down food material within the cell. It removes waste from the cell
Centrosome In cell biology, the centrosome is an organelle that is the main place where cell microtubules are organized. They occur only in animal cells. Also, it regulates the cell division cycle, the stages which lead up to cell division. A centrosome is composed of two centrioles at right angles to each another. They are surrounded by a shapeless mass of protein. This organelle is the place where microtubules get organized This organelle is composed of two centrioles at right angles to each other
Microtubules Microtubules are found in biological cells as a part of the cytoskeleton. They are hollow tubes whose walls consist of 13 columns of tubular molecules. Its main functions are to maintain a cell's shape, cell motility, chromosome movement in cell division, and organelle movement. They look like hollow noodles which transmit signals to our nerves These are responsible for maintaining a cells shape, and chromosome movement These organelles are hollow tubes, and look like hollow noodles

Plastids There are three main types of plastids, myloplasts, chloroplasts, and chromoplasts Chloroplasts generate energy through photosynthesis, which is then used to manufacture glucose and starch from carbon dioxide and water. Vacuoles Vacuoles are organelles which store different types of substances and help the cell grow. They can contain sugars, ions, or simply, water. In plant cells, vacuoles help keep the cell rigid. It stores different substances to help the cell grow
Peroxisome peroxisomes are similar to lysosomes. They differ from lysosomes in the type of enzyme they hold. Peroxisomes hold on to enzymes that require oxygen (oxidative enzymes). Lysosomes have enzymes that work in oxygen-poor areas and lower pH. They are very well known for digesting fatty acids. They also play a part in the way organisms digest alcohol (ethanol). These organelles hold on to enzymes that require oxygen
Plasmodesma Plasmodesma is a microscopic channel across the cell wall of a plant cell. It allows transport and communication between neighboring cells. Unlike animal cells, every plant cell is surrounded by a polysaccharide cell wall. These allow for communication and transportation of materials between cells
Cell Membrane The Cell membrane is the barrier that determines what is inside and what is outside the cell The membrane is made of proteins and can change forms as vacuoles and lysosomes combine to create a new membrane to expel wastes from the cell This is the barrier of the cell

Ecosystems In this module you will learn to identify and classify the major ecosystems on our planet
Desert Ecosystems The common defining feature among desert ecosystems is low precipitation, generally less than 25 centimeters per year. Not all deserts are hot – desert ecosystems can exist from the tropics to the arctic, but regardless of latitude, deserts are often windy. Vegetation is sparse or nonexistent, and any animal species, such as insects, reptiles and birds, must be highly adapted to the dry conditions. This type of ecosystem has very low precipitation
Forest Ecosystems Forest ecosystems are classified according to their climate type as tropical, temperate or boreal. In the tropics, rain forest ecosystems contain more diverse flora and fauna than ecosystems in any other region on earth. In temperate zones, forest ecosystems may be deciduous, coniferous or oftentimes a mixture of both, in which some trees shed their leaves each fall, while others remain evergreen year-round. In the far north, just south of the Arctic, boreal forests – also known as taiga – feature abundant coniferous trees. This type of ecosystem can either be tropical, temperate or boreal Rainforest's are a part of this ecosystem
Freshwater Ecosystems Freshwater ecosystems can be found in streams, rivers, springs, ponds, lakes, bogs and freshwater swamps. They are subdivided into two classes: those in which the water is nearly stationary, such as ponds, and those in which the water flows, such as creeks. Freshwater ecosystems are home to more than just fish: algae, plankton, insects, amphibians and underwater plants also inhabit them. This type of ecosystem can be divided into two classes, flowing and stationary water This type of ecosystem is home to fish, algae, plankton, and insects among others
Grassland Ecosystems Different types of grassland ecosystems can be found in prairies, savannas and steppes. Grassland ecosystems are typically found in tropical or temperate regions, although they can exist in colder areas as well, as is the case with the well-known Siberian steppe. Trees are sparse or nonexistent, but flowers may be interspersed with the grasses. Grasslands provide an ideal environment for grazing animals. This type of ecosystem can be found in prairies, savannas and steppes This type of ecosystem is ideal for grazing animals
Marine Ecosystems Marine ecosystems differ from freshwater ecosystems in that they contain saltwater, which usually supports different types of species than does freshwater. Marine ecosystems are the most abundant types of ecosystems in the word. They encompass not only the ocean floor and surface but also tidal zones, estuaries, salt marshes and saltwater swamps, mangroves and coral reefs. This is the most abundant type of ecosystem in the world This ecosystem contains tidal zones, salt marshes and saltwater swamps
Tundra Ecosystems In the snow-covered, windswept, treeless tundra, the soil may be frozen year-round, a condition known as permafrost. During the brief spring and summer, snows melt, producing shallow ponds which attract migrating waterfowl. The term “tundra” most commonly denotes polar areas, but at lower latitudes, tundra-like communities known as alpine tundra may be found at high elevations. This type of ecosystem can have a condition known as permafrost This type of ecosystem is commonly found in polar areas

Rocks and minerals Rocks and minerals are all around us, and they can be found from building materials to medicine and pharmaceuticals This module will introduce you to the three types of rocks, as well as some common rocks and minerals Geologists are scientists who study rocks. To a geologist, a rock and a mineral are two different things that occur in nature. Imagine two chocolate bars. One is pure chocolate, and the other has caramel and nuts in it. The pure chocolate bar is like a mineral. In science, a mineral is a solid that is made of the same substance throughout. The chocolate bar that contains nuts and caramel is like a rock. A rock is a solid that is made of two or more minerals.
Minerals All rocks are made of minerals. A mineral is a pure substance that forms naturally as a solid in Earth. Some rocks, such as limestone, are formed of only one mineral. Other rocks, such as granite, are made up of several minerals. Minerals are classified by their chemical composition (by what chemicals are in them). You may have heard the names of some of the most common minerals, such as quartz and mica. There are thousands of different minerals, and these can combine to form many kinds of rocks. you do not have to know thousands of minerals to be able to identify most of the rocks you will find. Just five minerals combine in different ways to form most of the rocks in Earth’s crust. These minerals are, calcite, quartz, feldspar, mica, hornblende Two rocks can have exactly the same minerals in them, but they may look different because they formed in different ways. The way the minerals are arranged and the sizes of the individual grains can all give clues to how a rock formed.
//new
Calcite Calcite is a common rock forming mineral Calcite is found in all 3 types of rocks It is used in all parts of our lives, from construction to pharmaceutical industries It is a common rock building mineral
Sedimentary rock rocks at or near Earth's surface are broken into smaller pieces by water, wind, and ice. Soil and shell pieces are also moved along with rock pieces. The pieces (called sediment) often settle in layers, such as in desert dunes and on the bottoms of rivers, lakes, and oceans. Over millions of years, the layers are squeezed together. The weight and pressure of the layers above cause the sediment to become cemented together to form new rock. This is how igneous, metamorphic, and older sedimentary rocks are recycled to become newsedimentary rocks. It is formed over time at the bottom of lakes
Igneous rock The rock shown here is Gnaisse which is a common form of igneous rock Igneous rocks are formed from volcanic activity, under high heat and pressure Igneous rock covers the ocean floor, so two- thirds of Earth’s surface is igneous rock! In fact, all types of rocks on Earth began as igneous rock. It is formed from volcanic activity
Limestone Limestone is a sedimentary rock It is often composed of the skeletal fragments of marine organisms such as coral It is often made of skeletal fragments of marine organisms
Quartz Quartz is a mineral made of silicon and oxygen It is the second most abundant material It is made of silicon and oxygen
Metamorphic rock A metamorphic rock is a type of rock which has been changed by extreme heat and pressure. Its name is from 'morph' (meaning form), and 'meta' (meaning change). The original rock may be sedimentary rock, igneous rock or another older metamorphic rock. for example marble is a metamorphic rock formed from limestone. This type of rock has been changed from extreme heat and pressure

Weathering Weathering is one of the reasons that rocks change. Weathering is the process that wears down rocks and other objects. Think back to the types of rock you studied earlier: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. Even though most of Earth’s crust is made of igneous rocks, many of the rocks we see on the surface are sedimentary rocks. Most sedimentary rocks form from tiny rock fragments piling up and being pressed together. Where did the fragments come from? Weathering breaks rocks into tiny pieces, which helps to form sedimentary rocks and soil. there are many different types of weathering, lets take a look at them!
Mechanical weathering Mechanical weathering happens when rock is broken apart by physical forces such as water or wind. In our climate, rock is often broken down by water freezing in cracks This type of weathering happens when rock is broken by physical forces, such as water This type of weathering can be caused by water or wind
Chemical weathering Chemical weathering happens when water in the air combines with chemical substances in the air. Sometimes these substances are in the air naturally. Sometimes they are there because of cars, fires, and smoke from industry. combined with the rain or snow, the substances form solutions called acids. Rocks exposed to these acids gradually wear away. This type of weathering happens when water is combined with chemical substances in the air This type of weathering can be caused by acids, cars, or smoke from fires
Biological weathering Biological weathering is the wearing away of rocks by living things. Even small plants can “chip away” at rocks. This type of weathering happens because of living thigns Small plants can cause this type of weathering
Erosion Erosion is the movement of rock materials and soil by water, wind, or ice. These rock materials can be as big as boulders or as small as the grains in soil. This is the movement of rock materials and soil by water, wind or ice
Deposition The settling of rock materials out of water, wind, or ice is called deposition. The material deposited is called sediment. These sediments form the sedimentary rock you learned about earlier in this unit. Sedimentary deposits usually form in layers. This is the settling of rock materials out of water, wind or ice This helps form sedimentary rocks

Greenhouse gases In this module you will learn about the common greenhouse gasses, and the effect they have on our atmosphere and climate
The Greenhouse effect Greenhouse gases reflect radiation that the Earth emits, and stop it from being lost into space. This causes the Earth's temperature to be higher than it would be without greenhouse gases. The name for this is the "greenhouse effect." This is the effect that causes radiation to be reflected back to Earth
Greenhouse gasses Most greenhouse gases are natural - water vapor is the most common, and causes most of the greenhouse effect on Earth. Other greenhouse gases are carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, chlorofluorocarbon and ozone. Without greenhouse gases, the earth would be on average 33 degrees Celsius colder. These are gasses that cause the greenhouse effect Without these gasses the earth would be 33 degrees colder
Water vapour Water vapour is the most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, both by weight and by volume Water vapour will generally stay in the atmosphere for days (before precipitating out) while other greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide or methane, will stay in the atmosphere for a much longer period of time (ranging from years to centuries) thus contributing to warming for an extended period of time. Increased water vapor content in the atmosphere is referred to as a feedback process. Warmer air is able to hold more moisture. As the climate warms, air temperatures rise, more evaporation from water sources and land occurs, thus increasing the atmospheric moisture content. The water vapour feedback process is most likely responsible for a doubling of the greenhouse effect when compared to the addition of carbon dioxide on its own This is the most abundant greenhouse gas This greenhouse gas causes a feedback loop that doubles the greenhouse effect
Carbon dioxide Carbon dioxide is a naturally occurring gas, that is released from decaying and living organisms, as well as volcanoes Carbon dioxide is also released when burning fossil fuels such as coal or oil, and it is the most important contributor to man-made greenhouse gasses This greenhouse gas is released by living and decaying organisms, as well as volcanoes This greenhouse gas is the most important contributor of man-made greenhouse gasses
Methane Methane is a normal gas released from wetlands, growing rise, raising cattle, using natural gas, and mining coal However, methane traps a lot of heat, and is considered the second most important contributor to man-made greenhouse gasses This greenhouse gas is released from wetlands, growing rice, and mining coal
Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide is a natural part of the nitrogen cycle, and is released from bacteria in the soil and ocean However, it is also released by some factories, power plants, and fertilizers. This gas damages the protective ozone layer, and is extremely powerful This gas damages the protective ozone layer

Water cycle Water is one of our most precious resources. This module will introduce you to the water cycle, one of the most important cycles for life on Earth
Evaporation Energy from the sun causes water to evaporate from bodies of water The main factors affecting evaporation are temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. The principal source of water vapour is the oceans, but evaporation also occurs in soils, snow, and ice. Around 90 percent of the water vapor in the atmosphere got there through evaporation. Through this process water rises to form clouds 90 percent of water vapor in the atmosphere comes from this process
Condensation Condensation is the process of water vapour forming clouds Water vapor gas condenses back into liquid water and ice, which you mainly see as clouds and then as rain and snow. Condensation happens because of temperature changes. This is the process during which water vapour forms clouds This is the process that forms clouds
Precipitation Precipitation is when water falls from the atmosphere back to land. Depending on the temperature and weather this could be rain, snow, sleet, or even hail. This is how water returns from clouds to the ground level Rain, snow, and hail are examples of this
Transpiration Transpiration is when plants release water on to their leaves that then evaporates into vapor. Around 10 percent of the water vapor in the atmosphere is estimated to come from transpiration. This is the process during which plants release water that is evaporated Around 10 percent of the water vapour in the atmosphere is estimated to come from here
