Our Solar System In this module you will learn about all of our planets in the solar system.
Sun The Sun is on average 149 600 000 km, or one astronomical unit (1AU), away from Earth. It takes about 9 min for light to travel from the Sun to Earth. The Sun creates its energy mainly by combining hydrogen nuclei to produce helium nuclei, in a process called nuclear fusion. In this process, the Sun releases energy in the form of light, heat, and radioactive material. At its core, the heat of the Sun is estimated to be over 15 000 000 °C. The Sun is a medium-sized star, called a yellow dwarf
Mercury Mercury is the smallest, and closest planet to the sun It has the greatest range of temperature, from as hot as 370 °C to as cold as –150 °C. How hot or cold it can be depends on which side is facing the Sun. It completes one full revolution around the sun in 88 days Mercury has no atmosphere
It is the smallest planet in the solar system
Venus Venus has a thick atmosphere, of carbon dioxide and sulfuric acid Not only does the cloud reflect light, it also traps heat on the planet, just like a greenhouse. The planet’s temperature can reach 484 °C — hot enough to melt lead. The “greenhouse effect” also affects the weather on the planet. Winds on Venus have been estimated to be 380 km/h. That’s faster than most tornadoes! Earth and Venus are about the same size and mass. Both have an iron core surrounded by a rocky surface. This is why Venus and Earth are called “twin” planets. This rocky surface also has a number of impact craters and mountains, but a lot of the surface of Venus has been shaped by volcanic activity. We also know that Venus spins in the opposite direction to Earth. This means that the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east. It has clouds made of acid
Earth Earth is the only known planet with life Earth's atmosphere is made up of about 80% nitrogen, and 20% oxygen 70% of Earth’s surface is covered by water. It is the only planet with oceans of warm water. The planet’s oceans help to keep Earth’s temperature fairly constant. The atmosphere also protects us from meteoroids. When a meteoroid, a fragment of space rock, enters Earth’s atmosphere, friction causes the meteoroid to burn up and be seen as the streak of bright light in a meteor. Some meteors and asteroids have hit Earth though. Scientists believe that Hudson Bay was created when an asteroid hit Earth millions of years ago. These impacts have helped to shape Earth’s surface, but the surface has also been created by volcanic and tectonic activity. Tectonic activity is the back-and-forth movement of “plates” that float on the top layer of Earth
The surface of this planet is 70% water
Mars temperatures range from –70 °C during its winter to 22 °C in the Martian summer. During the winter, ice caps which cover the south and north poles, increase after shrinking in the summer. These ice caps, however, are not made out of water. They are similar to dry ice. The atmosphere of Mars is thinner than that of Earth and gives less protection. The surface of Mars has been affected by the impact of meteorites, large fragments of space rock that may collide with planets. The surface of Mars is covered in a variety of rocks and an iron-rich clay soil. The planet gets its reddish appearance because the soil “rusts.” The surface is also covered with volcanoes, mountains, canals, and canyons. Some of these are the largest and deepest in the solar system.
This planet is covered in a layer of iron oxide
Jupiter Jupiter is the largest of all the planets. It is so large that all the other planets in our solar system could fit inside it. Jupiter has over 50 moons, some of which are as large as planets Because Jupiter rotates so quickly, its gases are stretched out into bands that go around the entire planet. The different colours of Jupiter are caused by the clouds that surround it. These clouds are made up of different materials and are at different heights. For example, the white bands are made of frozen ammonia, and the blue bands are made of water. These gas clouds help to create the weather on Jupiter as well. The most identifiable feature of Jupiter is its Great Red Spot. This red spot is actually a storm of clouds on the planet that has winds of over 320 km/h. It is just like a hurricane. It is the largest planet in our solar system
Saturn Saturn is made of mostly hydrogen and helium Saturn has rings made of dust and ice Saturn has over 52 moons One year on Saturn is over 10,759 Earth days
Saturn is best known for its impressive system of rings that surround this faint greenish-coloured gas giant. These rings measure 260 000 km across, but are only 14 m in thickness. Sometimes the rings look solid because they are made up of space “snowballs.” Some of these snowballs are as big as a house! Astronomers believe that the rings of Saturn come from the breakup of natural satellites that once revolved around the planet. Many satellites still orbit Saturn. Just like its neighbors, Saturn does not have a solid surface and it also has different-coloured spots. However, Saturn differs greatly from Jupiter. It is much lighter, or less dense. Since it is so light, and it rotates so quickly, Saturn’s shape is like a squished balloon. It oblates, or spreads out, along its equator. Much information on Saturn has been gained from space probes. The international Cassini mission has transmitted more than 140 000 images since 2004. This planet is famous for its rings
Uranus Uranus is the 7th planet from the sun, and the third gas giant, after Jupiter and Saturn Uranus has been tipped on its side, most likely by another planet Uranus has 27 moons named after characters from William Shakespeare
The third of the Gas Giants, Uranus is often called an “Ice Gas Giant” because its atmosphere is made up of different types of ices. One of the chemicals is methane. It is the methane gas that gives Uranus its blue-green colour. Its rings, which are a characteristic of all the Gas Giants, are very difficult to see. They were not discovered until 1977, and even the Hubble Space Telescope often has trouble seeing the 11 dark rings. \ Uranus is the only planet in our solar system to spin on its side, and, just like the planet Venus, it has retrograde motion. Astronomers believe that Uranus is on its side because it collided with a large object early in its history. Since Uranus is tilted so much, its north and south poles experience 42 years of light and 42 years of darkness. As well, each season lasts 21 years! This planet has been tipped on its side
Neptune Neptune is often compared to a large, round, blue Popsicle. This Popsicle has a centre (core) of melted rock. Around this rocky core is extremely cold water. Like its neighbor Uranus, Neptune gets its blue colour from methane. Remember how the Gas Giants create their own heat? Neptune is about 4.3 billion km from the Sun so any energy it gets from the Sun is much less than what we get on Earth. From this distance, the Sun looks like just another bright light in Neptune’s sky. The heat that Neptune produces creates hurricane-like storms on its frozen seas. These storms look like large, dark ovals on its surface. Neptune has some of the fiercest storms in the solar system, with winds reaching over 1900 km/h This is the farthest planet from the sun
Pluto Pluto is a dwarf planet It is mainly made of rock and ice It is the ninth largest body orbiting the sun

Chemical reactions Chemical reactions happen around us every day, from the reactions happening inside your cells that help keep you alive, to the reactions in cars and factories that allow our world to move. Understanding some basic chemical reactions are important to understand our world better! In this module you will learn about some common chemical reactions, what they are, and how they work
//synthesis
Creating water Water is the common name for dihydrogen monoxide or H2O. In theory, it's easy to make water from hydrogen gas and oxygen gas. Mix the two gases together, add a spark or sufficient heat to provide the activation energy to start the reaction, and presto—instant water. Merely mixing the two gases at room temperature, however, won't do anything, energy must be supplied to break the covalent bonds that hold H2 and O2 molecules together. When the chemical bonds re-form to make water, additional energy is released, which propagates the reaction. The net reaction is highly exothermic, meaning a reaction that is accompanied by the release of heat.
Photosynthesis Photosynthesis is the process by which plants and other things make food. It is a chemical process that uses sunlight to turn carbon dioxide into sugars the cell can use as energy. Light energy from the sun is used to split water molecules (photolysis). The sunlight hits chloroplasts in the plant, causing an enzyme to break apart the water. Water, when broken, makes oxygen, hydrogen, and electrons. Hydrogen, along with electrons energized by light, converts NADP into NADPH Oxygen diffuses out of the plant as a waste product of photosynthesis Plants use this chemical reaction to produce sugar and oxygen

It has a strong smell like bleach. It is toxic. It can be made into a liquid when cooled. It is heavier than air. When sodium and chlorine react, they form Sodium Chloride, or table salt. This reaction is highly exothermic, and produces a yellow glow and a lot of heat Table salt is a mineral composed mainly of sodium chloride (NaCl). This is a chemical compound, one of many salts. Salt in its natural form as a crystalline mineral is known as rock salt or halite.

Waves In this module you will learn about basic wave terminology There are lots of waves all around us in everyday life. Sound is a type of wave that moves through matter and then vibrates our eardrums, so we can hear. Light is a special kind of wave that is made up of photons. You can drop a rock into a pond and see waves form in the water. We even use waves (microwaves) to cook our food Waves can be divided into various categories depending on their characteristics. All waves can be categorized as either mechanical or electromagnetic.
Mechanical waves Mechanical waves are waves that require a medium. This means that they have to have some sort of matter to travel through. These waves travel when molecules in the medium collide with each other passing on energy. One example of a mechanical wave is sound. Sound can travel through air, water, or solids, but it can't travel through a vacuum. It needs the medium to help it travel. Other examples include water waves, seismic waves, and waves travelling through a spring. This type of wave requires a medium Sound waves are an example of this type of wave This type of wave cannot travel through a vacuum Water waves are this type of wave
Electromagnetic waves Electromagnetic waves are waves that can travel through a vacuum (empty space). They don't need a medium or matter. They travel through electrical and magnetic fields that are generated by charged particles. Examples of electromagnetic waves include light, microwaves, radio waves, and X-rays. This type of wave doesn't require a medium Microwaves are this type of wave Radio waves are this type of wave Light is this kind of wave
travelling waves Another way to describe a wave is by the direction that its disturbance is travelling. We can categorize waves into two categories, transverse and longitudinal waves
Transverse waves Transverse waves are waves where the disturbance moves perpendicular to the direction of the wave. You can think of the wave moving left to right, while the disturbance moves up and down. One example of a transverse wave is a water wave where the water moves up and down as the wave passes through the ocean. This type of wave causes disturbances perpendicular to the direction of the wave Water waves move in this type of way
Longitudinal waves Longitudinal waves are waves where the disturbance moves in the same direction as the wave. One example of this is a wave moving through a stretched out slinky or spring. If you compress one portion of the slinky and let go, the wave will move left to right. At the same time, the disturbance (which is the coils of the springs moving), will also move left to right. Another classic example of a longitudinal wave is sound. As sound waves propagate through a medium, the molecules collide with each other in the same direction as the sound is moving. Sound waves move in this type of way This type of wave causes a disturbance in the same direction as the wave
//6 Amplitude The amplitude of a wave is a measure of the displacement of the wave from its rest position, in other words, it is how high/low the wave goes In the case of water waves this can be thought of as the height of the wave, the higher the wave the larger the amplitude The amplitude is a measure of the strength or intensity of the wave. For example, when looking at a sound wave, the amplitude will measure the loudness of the sound. The energy of the wave also varies in direct proportion to the amplitude of the wave. This is the measure of the displacement of the wave This can be thought of as the height of the wave This is a measure of the strength or intensity of the wave This represents the loudness for sound waves
//7 WavelengthThe wavelength of a wave is the distance between two corresponding points on back-to-back cycles of a wave.This can be measured between two crests of a wave or two troughs of a wave. The wavelength is usually represented in physics by the Greek letter lambda (λ).In the term of water waves this can be thought of as how "long" the waves areThis measures the distance between two corresponding points on back to back cycles of a wave
//8 Frequency and PeriodThe frequency of a wave is the number of times per second that the wave cycles. Frequency is measured in Hertz or cycles per second. The frequency is often represented by the lower case "f."The period of the wave is the time between wave crests. The period is measured in time units such as seconds. The period is usually represented by the upper case "T."The period and frequency are closely related to each other. The period equals 1 over the frequency and the frequency is equal to one over the period. They are reciprocals of each other
//9 Velocity of a WaveAnother important property of a wave is the speed of propagation. This is how fast the disturbance of the wave is moving. The speed of mechanical waves depends on the medium that the wave is travelling through. For example, sound will travel at a different speed in water than in air.velocity = frequency * wavelength or v = f * λ

Biochemistry Biochemistry is the application of chemistry in biology. Biochemistry helps us understand the reactions and chemicals that are found in living things In this module you will learn about the basics of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acid, as well as cellular respiration
Nucleic Acids Nucleic acids are large molecules where genetic information is stored. There are two types of nucleic acids: deoxyribonucleic acid, better known as DNA and ribonucleic acid, better known as RNA. Nucleic acids allow organisms to transfer genetic information from one generation to the next. When a cell divides, its DNA is copied and passed from one cell generation to the next generation. DNA is organized into chromosomes and found within the nucleus of our cells. Its function in any cell is to carry the sequence of bases which will be transcribed into RNA. RNA then has many functions within the cell These molecules are responsible for passing on genetic information These molecules are used to create another important molecule known as RNA These molecules are organized into chromosomes
Carbohydrate Carbohydrates are chemical compounds that contain only oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. They are made up of joined-up sugars. Sugars have the general formula Cm(H2O)n, and are also known as saccharides. Certain carbohydrates are an important storage and transport form of energy in most organisms, including plants and animals. Carbohydrates are very good for energy, but, if a person eats more than needed, the extra is changed into fat. These molecules are very good for energy, however if too much of them are eaten, they are changed into fat These molecules are made of joined-up sugars
Cellular respiration Cellular respiration is what cells do to break up sugars into a form that the cell can use as energy. Cellular respiration takes in food and uses it to create ATP, a chemical which the cell uses for energy. Usually, this process uses oxygen, and is called aerobic respiration. It also produces carbon dioxide as a waste product, which then enters the circulatory system. The carbon dioxide is taken to the lungs, where it is exchanged for oxygen. The equation for this process is Glucose (sugar) + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy (as ATP) But how do the chemical enter the cell? Let's take a look The process in which particles enter the cell is called diffusion. Diffusion means particles move from areas of high concentration to areas of lower concentration. This happens naturally, however, the cells membrane can also control what enters and leaves the cell So, the cell membrane allows the particles of some substances to pass through it, but not others. Scientists say that the cell membrane is selectively permeable. One substance that can pass through the cell membrane is oxygen. >This movement of oxygen happens by diffusion, and it happens naturally. Because the concentration of oxygen is usually higher outside the cell membrane than it is inside. As a result, oxygen simply diffuses into the cell. The cell does not have to do anything. The diffusion of water is vital to the survival and health of cells. For this reason, scientists give it a special name: osmosis
Every cell does this to produce energy This process relies on diffusion and osmosis
Proteins Proteins are long-chain molecules built from small units known as amino acids. They are joined together with peptide bonds. Proteins are essential to all cells. Proteins take part in virtually every process in cells Proteins do different things depending on their shape. They can be found in meat or muscle. They are used for growth and repair, making tissue cells and used for strengthening the bones. There are four things that determine what a protein will do. The first is the order of the amino acids. The second is the little twists in the chain. The third is how the entire thing is folded up. The fourth is whether it is made up of different sub-units These molecules are made up of small units known as amino acids These molecules are found in large numbers in meat and muscle These molecules are used for growth, repair, making tissue cells and strengthening bones among others
Lipids A lipid is a type of organic molecule found in living things. It is oily or waxy. Fats are made from lipid molecules. Sources of lipid can be found in algae, seeds, meat, cheese, butter and fish. Lipids are long chains of carbon and hydrogen molecules. Lipids are classified as simple and complex. Examples of complex molecules could be steroids or phospholipids. A very important biological function of lipids is as lipid bilayers, the basis of many cell membranes. Another function of lipids is to serve as an energy reserve. In summary, lipids are a group of naturally occurring molecules that include fats, waxes, sterols, fat-soluble vitamins (such as vitamins A, D, E, and K), glycerides, phospholipids, and others. The main biological functions of lipids include storing energy, signalling, and acting as components of cell membranes. These molecules naturally occurs in fats, waxes and fat-soluble vitamins These molecules are classified as either simple or complex The main functions of this molecule include signalling, storing energy, and building the cell membrane

Human Organs In this module, you will learn about the most important organs in the human body
Heart The Heart's function is to pump blood throughout the body The Heart is considered a muscle The heart consists of four different chambers: the left atrium, the right atrium, the left ventricle and the right ventricle. This organ is made up of four different chambers
BrainThe Brain allows us to think, store memories, analyze and make judgments while at the same time controlling other areas automatically, such as breathing.The human brain weighs 1.36 kilograms and is made up of 60% fat. Lungs Blood runs through our body, goes to the lungs to pick up oxygen from the air we breathe in and then drops off carbon dioxide, which we breathe out. Ecological interaction In this module you will learn about the different interactions in a food web and food chain
Food chain Every living plant and animal must have energy to survive. Plants rely on the soil, water, and the sun for energy. Animals rely on plants as well as other animals for energy. In an ecosystem, plants and animals all rely on each other to live. Scientists sometimes describe this dependence using a food chain or a food web. A food chain describes how different organisms eat each other, starting out with a plant and ending with an animal.
Food Web In any ecosystem there are many food chains and, generally, most plants and animals are part of several chains. When you draw all the chains together you end up with a food web. This describes an ecosystem with many food chains
Food pyramid The food pyramid describes how energy moves through a food web. It also explains why there are fewer animals in the higher levels ecological pyramid. In an ecological pyramid there are always: more producers than herbivores, more herbivores than omnivores, more omnivores than carnivores A plant uses as much as 90 percent of the energy it gets from its food to support its life functions. The rest is stored in its roots, leaves, and other plant parts. That is all the energy that is available to the herbivore or omnivore that eats the plant—about 10 percent. The herbivore or omnivore also uses as much as 90 percent of the energy from its plant food to support its life functions. What do you think that means for a carnivore that eats the herbivore or omnivore? For a top carnivore?
Trophic Levels Sometimes scientists describe each level in a food web with a trophic level. Here are the five trophic levels: Level 1: Plants (producers) Level 2: Animals that eat plants or herbivores (primary consumers) Level 3: Animals that eat herbivores (secondary consumers, carnivores) Level 4: Animals that eat carnivores (tertiary consumers, carnivores) Level 5: Animals at the top of the food chain are called apex predators. Nothing eats these animals. These levels describe each level in a food web

Plate Tectonics In this module you will learn about plate tectonics, their different types, and how they shape our world
Earths crust The crust is the thinnest layer of our planet. Its average thickness is about 30 km under the continents, but it is only about 5–10 km thick under the oceans. Under big mountain ranges such as the Rocky Mountains, the crust can be up to 90 km thick. The total distance from the surface of the crust to Earth’s centre is about 6400 km. The soil, plants, and even the oceans that we see on the surface form only a thin covering on the crust. The crust is made of solid rock.
Continental drift Observations led Alfred Wegener to propose the theory of continental drift in about 1912. His theory was that the continents drifted to their current location. He suggested that they started as a single supercontinent called Pangaea. Alfred, like earlier scientists, had noted that the coasts of South America and Africa could fit together. He also saw similar structures along the two coastlines. They share similar rock formations and fossils. He suggested that the drift began about 200 million years ago.
Theory of plate tectonics this information to develop the theory of plate tectonics. This theory says Earth’s lithosphere (the upper mantle and crust) is broken into large plates. Earthquakes and volcanoes tend to occur where these plates meet.
Divergent boundaries In some places, the plates are pulling apart. New crust is pushed up from below. These are called divergent boundaries, and they create rifts or valleys. Large lakes sometimes form in rifts. These places create rifts or valleys Sometimes, large lakes form because of these boundaries
Transform boundaries A transform boundary happens when plates slide past each other but neither collide nor rip apart. The San Andreas Fault in California is a transform boundary. The third type of boundary is a transform boundary. Here, plates slide along beside each other. But this sliding does not happen smoothly. The rocks bind and catch on each other, causing earthquakes. You can find a transform boundary along the west coast of Canada. At these boundaries, plates slide past each other The San Andreas fault is an example of this boundary You can find this boundary along the west coast of Canada
Convergent boundaries At converging boundaries, plates come together. Although plates move just centimetres each year, they are so huge that we experience the effects of their collision. We can feel the earthquakes and see the mountains, including volcanoes, that grow at or near these boundaries. There are two kinds of converging boundaries. One kind of converging boundary happens where a trench forms. One plate carries oceanic crust, and the other one carries continental crust. As they push together, the heavier, thinner oceanic crust is forced down below the lighter, thicker continental crust. As one grinds down past the other, earthquakes rumble, and the continental crust wrinkles to form mountains. The oceanic crust moves lower into Earth and gets hotter and melts. This molten rock rises in some places to form volcanoes. These boundaries create mountains Earthquakes, montains and volcanoes all happen near these boundaries

Weather Weather is the day-to-day or hour-to-hour change in the atmosphere. Weather includes wind, lightning, storms, hurricanes, tornadoes, rain, hail, snow, and lots more. Weather happens because different parts of the Earth get different amounts of heat from the Sun. This makes different climates. The tropics get the most heat because the Sun shines straight down on them, while the poles get the least heat because the Sun shines on them from a low angle. Weather is very important to life on Earth, it covers everything from rain, and storms to temperature Meteorology is the scientific study of weather. Meteorologists are people who study and predict, or forecast, the weather. Meteorology began in the 17th century when many instruments were invented to measure different weather conditions. Lets take a look at some important aspects for weather
Atmosphere Air surrounds Earth like a blanket. This blanket of air is called the atmosphere. It is made up of many kinds of gases. It also contains dust particles and water. Earth's atmosphere is the layer of gases around the Earth. The atmosphere is held in place by Earth's gravity. The atmosphere is made of about 80% Nitrogen and 20% Oxygen, with small amounts of other gasses, such as carbon dioxide These are layers of gasses surrounding Earth
//this is the simpler version
Weather Scientists have divided the atmosphere into four different layers. We live in the bottom layer, and this is where weather occurs. In fact, scientists define weather as the condition of the atmosphere at any particular time and place. This is the condition of the atmosphere at any particular time and place This the day-to-day and hour-to-hour change in the atmosphere
Air according to scientists, air is made up of different kinds of tiny particles. These particles are always moving. They bump into each other, and they bump into everything around them. Air pushes on trees, buildings, bicycles, furniture, and even you! Air pushes in all directions— up, down, and sideways. This pushes you in all directions, although you don't notice it
Temperature As the air around us heats up or cools down, we experience different temperatures. Temperature is a measure of how hot or cold something is. We measure air temperature in order to find out how hot or cold the air is. Air temperature decreases as you move farther from Earth and higher up into the atmosphere. This is a measure of how hot or cold something is
Troposphere The troposphere starts at the ground, this is the layer of the atmosphere that we live in. It starts at the ground and ends somewhere between 7 and 14 kilometres. The higher, the colder. Weather in this layer affects our daily life. This is the ground layer of the atmosphere Weather in this atmosphere affects our daily life
Stratosphere This layer starts at 7 to 14 kilometres. Ends at 50 kilometres. The higher, the hotter. There is little water vapour and other substances in this layer. Airplanes fly in this layer because it is usually stable and air resistance is small. Airplanes usually fly in this layer of the atmosphere
Mesosphere this layer start at 50 kilometres. Ends at 80 or 85 kilometres. The higher, the colder. Winds in this layer are strong, so the temperature is not stable. The winds are very strong in this layer, and the temperature is not stable
Thermosphere Starts at 80 or 85 kilometres. Ends at 640 kilometres or higher. The higher, the hotter. This layer is very important in radio communication because it helps to reflect AM radio waves. This layer of the atmosphere helps reflect AM radio waves
Exosphere This layer is above the thermosphere. This is the top layer, and merges into interplanetary space. This layer of the atmosphere merges into interplanetary space

Living things Are made up of one or more cells. Cells are the smallest units of life. Sometimes cells are separated by cell walls. Respire (breathe). Animals take in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide. Plants take in carbon dioxide, sunlight, and water to make sugars and oxygen. Plants give off water vapour and oxygen. Require energy to live. Plants use energy from the Sun to make food substances; animals depend on plants and other animals as food. Respond to stimuli in their environment. Animals and plants move and/or react to changes around them. Grow and develop. In many organisms there is a change from the form at the beginning of life through a juvenile form to the adult stage. Cells divide, causing changes over a time period; this is referred to as a life cycle. Reproduce. Living things create offspring, to produce a new generation of their kind. Offspring are related to their parents. Excrete (get rid of wastes). People get rid of their body wastes in a toilet. We also excrete carbon dioxide when we breathe out. Plants excrete oxygen as a waste product, and some plants put their wastes into leaves that die off in the fall The scientific terms for living and non-living things are biotic and abiotic.
Water Living Things Need Water. About three-quarters of Earth’s surface is covered with water. Water also makes up the majority of all living things. For example, about two-thirds of your body is made up of water. About nine-tenths (or more) of a head of lettuce is water! Life cannot exist without water. This makes up the majority of living things, including about two-thirds of you!
Energy All living things need energy. Energy is the ability to do work and to cause physical or chemical changes. Plants need energy to grow, produce seeds, and repair damage. Some plants, such as sunflowers, even use energy to move. You need energy to walk, breathe, eat, digest what you eat, and grow. You need energy even when you are sitting still. Energy keeps your heart beating, air moving in and out of your lungs, and the rest of your organs working properly. You even need energy when you are asleep! This is what allows plants and animals to do work, such as grow, and repair damage You need this even when you sleep, to keep your heart beating, and air moving in and out of your lungs
Food You need food for nutrients. Nutrients include substances such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, and minerals. All these substances supply your body with energy and materials that you need to move, grow, and repair and maintain the health of the billions of cells in your body. All other living things need nutrients for the same reason. You need these materials to help you grow, move and repair yourself You need this for nutrients, such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins and minerals
Oxygen Living things need oxygen. When you eat, chemical reactions take place inside your body. These reactions use oxygen to release the energy in food. With only a few exceptions, all living things need oxygen to get the energy they need to survive. This includes animals; plants; fungi, such as mushrooms; and microscopic life forms, such as bacteria. This is necessary to help the chemical reactions take place in your body, that turn food into energy This gas is needed for the reactions that relesae energy in food
Suitable Living conditions Living Things Need Suitable Living Conditions. Life can exist in some very harsh conditions. For example, some kinds of microscopic bacteria and algae thrive in hot springs that can reach temperatures of up to 85 °C. Other kinds of life exist in the Antarctic, where temperatures can reach as low as –90 °C. However, most living things live best in a more moderate range of temperatures. Some animals build shelters for protection from harsh weather.

Weather and climate In this module, you will learn about the different types of climates on planet Earth First, lets understand the difference between weather and climate Climate tells us what kinds of weather usually happen in an area at different times of the year. Weather, on the other hand, is the hour-to-hour and day-to-day change in temperate. The climate tells us what kind of weather to expect If you live in a desert climate, you can expect hot and dry weather, if you live in a rainforest climate, you can expect lots of rain! In the next lesson you'll learn more about weather, now lets take a look at the different climates
Climate Climate means the usual condition of the temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, rainfall, and other meteorological elements in an area of the Earth's surface for a long time. This is the difference between weather and climate. Weather is the condition right now, for example if it is cold, that is the weather. But some places are colder for longer than others, this depends on the climate
Rainforests Rainforests are characterized by high rainfall, with definitions setting minimum normal annual rainfall between 1,750 millimetres and 2,000 millimetres. Mean monthly temperatures exceed 18 °C during all months of the year. This climate is characterized by high rainfall The average temperature is over 18 °C during all months of the year
monsoon A monsoon is a seasonal prevailing wind which lasts for several months, ushering in a region's rainy season. Regions within North America, South America, Sub-Saharan Africa, Australia and East Asia are monsoon regimes. This is a seasonal prevailing wind that lasts several months, and brings in a regions rainy season
tropical savanna A tropical savanna is a grassland located in semiarid to semi-humid climate regions of subtropical and tropical latitudes, with average temperatures remain at or above 18 °C year round and rainfall between 750 millimetres and 1,270 millimetres a year. They are widespread on Africa, and are found in India, the northern parts of South America, Malaysia, and Australia. This is a grassland located in a semi-humid climate region, with average temperature remaining at or above 18 °C
humid subtropical The humid subtropical climate zone where winter rainfall (and sometimes snowfall) is associated with large storms that the westerlies steer from west to east. Most summer rainfall occurs during thunderstorms and from occasional tropical cyclones. Humid subtropical climates lie on the east side of continents, roughly between latitudes 20° and 40° degrees away from the equator. Most of the summer rainfall in this region occurs during thunderstorms and tropical cyclones
humid continental A humid continental climate is marked by variable weather patterns and a large seasonal temperature variance. Places with more than three months of average daily temperatures above 10 °C and coldest months temperatures are below −3 °C and which do not meet the criteria for an arid or semiarid climate, are classified as continental. This has a large seasonal temperature change
oceanic climate An oceanic climate is typically found along the west coasts at the middle latitudes of all the world's continents, and in southeastern Australia, and is accompanied by plentiful precipitation year-round. This climate is found along the west coasts at the middle altitudes of all the worlds continents
Mediterranean climate The Mediterranean climate regime resembles the climate of the lands in the Mediterranean Basin, parts of western North America, parts of Western and South Australia, in southwestern South Africa and in parts of central Chile. The climate is characterized by hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. This climate is characterized by hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters
steppe A steppe is a dry grassland with an annual temperature range in the summer of up to 40 °C and during the winter down to −40 °C. This is a dry grassland with a large temperature range going from 40 °C to -40 °C
subarctic climate A subarctic climate has little precipitation, and monthly temperatures which are above 10 °C for one to three months of the year, with permafrost in large parts of the area due to the cold winters. Winters within subarctic climates usually include up to six months of temperatures averaging below 0 °C. This place has very little precipitation, and has permafrost in large parts of the area due to cold winters
Tundra Tundra occurs in the far Northern Hemisphere, north of the taiga belt, including vast areas of northern Russia and Canada. This climate occurs in the Northern Hemisphere, and includes large areas of northern Russia and Canada
polar ice cap A polar ice cap, or polar ice sheet, is a high-altitude region that is covered in ice. Ice caps form because high-latitude regions receive less energy as solar radiation from the sun than equatorial regions, resulting in lower surface temperatures This is a high-altitude region that is covered in ice
desert A desert is a landscape form or region that receives very little precipitation. Deserts usually have a large diurnal and seasonal temperature range, with high or low, depending on location daytime temperatures (in summer up to 45 C), and low nighttime temperatures (in winter down to 0 °C) due to extremely low humidity. Many deserts are formed by rain shadows, as mountains block the path of moisture and precipitation to the desert. This region receives very little precipitation, and has a very large temperature changes ranging from 45 °C to 0 °C in one day

Respiratory System Breathing helps bring oxygen into your body and take carbon dioxide out of your body. Scientists call this process respiration. Your respiratory system is made up of all the cells, tissues, and organs that work together to make respiration happen. You use this system every time you breathe, but also when you cough, sneeze, speak, or move. The main organs in your respiratory system are your two lungs This system helps bring oxygen into your body, and take carbon dioxide out This system is responsible for respiration This system is used whenever you breathe, cough, sneeze, speak or move The main organs in this system are your two lungs
Circulatory system Your circulatory system, which includes your heart, blood, and blood vessels, works with your respiratory system to move oxygen and nutrients throughout your body. Blood flows constantly through hollow tubes in your body called blood vessels. Two types of blood vessels are arteries and veins. Arteries carry blood away from your heart. Veins carry blood back to your heart. Scientists call the movement of blood around your body circulation.
Your heart is an organ about the size of your fist. It is made up of muscle tissue, which can tighten and relax Make a fist and notice how the muscles in your hand tighten. Now relax your hand. Do you feel the difference? This is how heart muscle works. When heart muscle tightens, blood flows out of the heart. When heart muscle relaxes, blood flows into the heart. The left side of your heart pumps oxygen-rich blood that comes from your lungs to the rest of your body. As your cells use oxygen, they make carbon dioxide and other waste that the blood carries away. Blood is like a server who delivers lunch to your cells and then takes away the leftovers and garbage. The blood carrying wastes returns to the right side of the heart, which then sends it to the lungs. You inhale fresh air, the blood releases its carbon dioxide and picks up more oxygen, and the whole cycle starts all over again. And it all happens in about a minute!
This system works with your respiratory system to move oxygen and nutrients throughout your body The main organ in this system is your heart
Digestive system Your body needs fuel to grow and to function properly, the same way a car needs fuel to run. Oxygen, nutrients, and water are the fuel for your body. Oxygen comes from the air, and nutrients come from food. Your digestive system breaks down the food so that your body can absorb the nutrients. The main part of your digestive system is a tube about nine metres long. It goes from your mouth to your anus, which is part of your small intestine. Many organs are part of this tube or attached to it. They include your stomach, liver, and intestines. Your digestive system is like a giant food processor: it chops, mashes, and mixes food into a soupy paste. The food’s journey through the digestive system starts in the mouth, when you chew and swallow. Moist pieces of food then travel down your esophagus and into your stomach, and later into your intestines. There, digestive juices attack the food and break it down into even smaller pieces. Throughout your digestive system, chemicals called enzymes help break down food into nutrients. Some of the chemicals that help your body digest food are made or stored in the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder. This system breaks down food so that your body can absorb the nutrients The main part of this system is a tube about nine meters long
Excretory system Your body creates other waste products that it must get rid of. You already know about carbon dioxide, which exits your body through your respiratory system. Other waste products are removed by your excretory system. You have two kidneys that clean your blood and then return it to your circulatory system. The waste liquid left behind is called urine. The urine leaves each kidney though a tube called a ureter. The ureters are connected to your bladder. When your bladder is full, it sends a signal to your brain that you need to urinate. This system is responsible for removing waste from your body The main organs in this system are your two kidneys Urinating is handled by this system
Nervous system As you have learned, the brain controls many processes in your body. The brain is your body’s main control centre. This organ sends and receives messages through your spinal cord and nerves. The brain, spinal cord, and nerves make up your nervous system. Your brain processes information from your nerves so that you know what you see, smell, hear, feel, and taste. Your brain lets you know whether you are hot, or hungry, or in pain. Your brain also sends signals to all the other systems in your body to control your body’s activities, from walking to sweating. Your brain also uses hormones to communicate. Hormones are chemicals that act as messengers between body systems. You might remember your mouth watering after having smelled something good to eat. This is your digestive juices preparing for the intake of food. Your digestive system then takes over to digest the cookie. The main organ in this system is your brain This system is what allows you to see, smell, hear, feel and taste This system controls all other systems in your body
musculoskeletal system The bones in your body form a skeleton, or framework, that holds your body up and gives it a shape. Many muscles work together with bones so that you can move, stand, and sit up. These muscles and bones are part of your musculoskeletal system. Your musculoskeletal system also protects the organs and tissues inside your body. Skeletal muscles are the muscles attached to bones. They are held to the bones by tendons. Tendons are long strips of tough tissue. Tendons help your body move but keep your bones from being pulled too far out of position. You can feel tendons in your ankles and at the back of your knees. A joint is formed where two bones connect, elbows, knees, and knuckles are all joints. There are 206 bones in the human skeleton. Most skeletal muscles are attached to bones on both sides of a joint. Muscles pull on the bones at a joint to cause movement. Muscles can pull but not push, so muscles often work in pairs to move different parts of your body. This system helps protect the organs and tissues inside your body This system is what allows you to move Tendons help this system work

Diseases Diseases occur when organs or systems are not working properly. If an organ has a disease, has failed (is not functioning at all), or is missing, the body systems it belongs to may not work properly. For example, when someone is having a heart attack, the artery that carries blood to the heart is blocked. Blood cannot reach the heart and the heart muscle may start to die. If blood cannot reach your heart, your heart cannot pump it out to the rest of your body. This occurs when organs or systems don't work properly
Germs Germs are tiny living things that can cause sickness or disease. Germs include bacteria and viruses. Germs can get into your body through a break in the skin, such as a scratch or cut. Germs can also get in through your mouth, nose, ears, or eyes. If this happens, your body’s deferences prepare to fight! These include bacteria and viruses These can get into your body through a break in the skin, or through your mouth nose, ears and eyes
Immune system Your body’s immune system works to destroy any germs that get into your body. This system includes special cells, such as white blood cells, and organs that produce these cells. The organs in your immune system are located all around your body. They include your tonsils (two in the back of your throat) and your spleen (near your stomach). When your body senses an intruder, your immune system increases the number of the special cells that can fight it. Your circulatory system then carries these cells to the site of the infection to fight off the intruder. The number of white blood cells in your body increases when you have an infection. This sytem helps detect and destroy any germs in your body This system includes special cells called white blood cells

Newtons First Law Newtons First Law says that an object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion, with the same direction and speed For example, if you watch videos of astronauts in space, you will notice that their tools float, and they won't move unless the astronaut pushes or pulls it, at which point it will keep moving until it is stopped This law states that an object will stay at rest, or continue in motion unless acted on by an external force It is because of this law that objects on ice travel so far

Scientific Method The scientific method is a logical and structured way of thinking about our world. It focuses on using observations and evidence, instead of just gut feeling and guesses This is a logical way of thinking about our world
Observation Whenever we encounter something we do not have an explanation for, we could consider it an observation. It is important that we try to consider only what is observed, and ignore any previous assumptions or guesses This is the first step in the scientific method This step is where we notice something we cannot explain
Ask a question After we observe something unexplainable, we should ask the question "why ...", and attempt to answer it This is the second step in the scientific method
Hypothesis A hypothesis is a testable explanation for something we observed. This is a testable explanation This is the third step in the scientific method In this step, we come up with a guess for our observation
Experiment We use an experiment to try to test our hypothesis. During the experiment, we should try and isolate for only the variables in our hypothesis Our experiment should also be reproducible, such that others can also test our hypothesis This is the fourth step in the scientific method This is the process of testing out hypothesis In this step, we try to isolate a single variable and test for it This must be reproducible
Prediction We predict what will happen during our experiment, using our hypothesis. Our prediction will be either wrong, partially wrong, or correct This is the fifth step in the scientific method In this step we guess what will happen during our experiment
Validation and repeat After our experiment, we may have new questions or observations. We then repeat the process of the scientific method This is the last step in the scientific method

Shop Here you can spend your well-earned Dive points! Currently, you can purchase a variety of e-gift cards. Enter the tutorial in the shop to learn more
Dive Points As you learn and discover more, you will be rewarded with Dive points. You can use Dive points to purchase things from the shop!
About Me Here you can keep track of your progress, view and edit your learning plan and see all your past achievements
//about me panel
Student Information This is where all the results from your past tests and quizzes are kept, to help you keep track of your progress over time Be sure to visit this page often, to see how you've improved and set new goals to help keep you motivated (and earn some Dive points!) This is also where you can edit your learning plans. If you want to change the difficulty of the questions, change the topics you learn or anything else to do with your learning plan then come here
Achievements This is where all of your past certificates and medals are stored! If you want to earn extra Dive points, be sure to share your achievements with your friends, by clicking the "Share" button!
//back to student image
Start Learning Click this when you want to start learning!
//main menu
Menu This menu can be found in any scene, simply click the three bars to open it
Back Button Click this button to go back to the previous screen
Quit App When you are finished with your learning session, just click this button to make sure all your progress and points are saved!
Settings click this button to change the settings for the game If you ever run into a problem (something doesn't work, or make sense, or maybe a spelling error) than please go to the settings and click on Report Problem!
Back to Home Click this button to return to the home page at any time
Tutorial Click this button to get the tutorial for the current scene. Use this button anytime you are confused!
Bon Voyage That's the end of this tutorial! Have fun learning! Click here to continue
Shop Here you can spend your well-earned Dive points. To buy a prize, simply click on the prize you wish to buy, and enter the amount of Dive points you would like to spend, remember, 500 Dive points is 1 dollar
//buying panel
Email This is the email address the e-gift cards will be sent to, make sure its right! If not, we will be unable to send you your gift cards
Gift Card Amount Here enter how many Dive points you would like on your gift card. It must be less than your balance and current Dive points limit.
Student Information Here you can find your learning plan, your goals, and your past progress
Past Quizzes In this panel you can see all of your past quiz scores. You can find exactly which topics you are struggling with, and which one's you know well. You can take tests and quizzes as many times as you like with no penalty. In the graph only the most recent scores are shown, to see all of your past scores click on the topic you are interested in.
Goals Here you can change and add goals. Goals help you stay motivated and track your progress. If you set and complete a good goal, then you will receive a certificate and Dive points! To add a goal, simply drag up to three of the topics you would like to work on into the goals section When you do, Dive will automatically give you a good goal. You can drag the slider on the right to change your goal. However, if you change it to less than the default, it is no longer a "good" goal, and you will not receive points for completing it If you want to change your goals or add new ones, click the "Clear goals" button below
Edit Plan Here you can edit your learning plan for this subject. Your learning plan is exactly which topics, in which order, and in what difficulty you learn You can also write a quick placement test, and Dive will automatically choose the right topics, order and difficulty for you so you can spend less time worrying and more time learning!
//breakdown panel
Breakdown In this page, you can see all of your past scores in that topic. This way you can see improvement as you learn and understand more!
//student info
Certificates Earn certificates by completing lessons and goals. You can share certificates with your friends for extra Dive Points!
Learning plan Here you can change the order, the topics, and the difficulty of questions in this subject
Current topics Here you can see all the current topics that are in your plan. Topics are sorted into similar groups based on their colours. To remove a topic, drag it to the left, to learn more about a topic and change its difficulty, click on it. To change the order of topics, just drag and drop them here
Other topics Here you can see all topics that are not included in your plan, but can be added for your current grade and subject To add a new topic, simply drag it from here into the middle section, and place it in the position you would like
Topic information Here you can find information about the current topic The name is shown at the top, followed by an example questions, and finally the difficulty. To change the difficulty, simply move the slider. If you changed the difficulty, make sure you click "Save" to save your selection
Redo learning plan If you would like to create a learning plan, simply click this button! Dive will give you a short quiz, to find exactly which topics you need to practice, and which topics you know well Then, we will create a new learning plan for you, and choose the best topics, order and difficulty to help you learn best!
//the grades
Grades Select a grade to continue learning Science Note: it doesn't matter which grade you choose, and it doesn't have to be your current grade, if you are in grade 7 feel free to learn science in Grade 5 or in Grade 10!
Module Menu Here, you can choose from a variety of science modules. To scroll, click and drag with your mouse, than simply click on any of the topics you wish to learn. There are a few different ways that science is taught, lets explore!
//module menu with the popup showing
Learning a new topic When you click on a lesson, you can either do the lesson, or a quiz
//have a model of planets, showing earth
Swipe-able Models At Dive, we believe in learning science by discovery For some topics, you can see different models by swiping left or right If you want to learn more information about a model, then simply click on it Make sure you click on each model! Some models have parts inside them which are also clickable, feel free to take your time and explore
//show cells
Click-able Models Here, the material is taught using visual 3d models. Each model is interactive, simply click on it to select it! When a model is selected, its name is shown at the top, and an animation is shown to see the model in more detail To learn more about the model, click it again. This will pull up the information panel for the model
//show greenhouse
Click-able Labels Sometimes, you will need to click on the labels in the scene to get more information When you have learned more about the models, and want to test your knowledge, click the space bar, this will bring up the menu, then simply click "start quiz"
Dots Everything that can be clicked on has a dot on it To toggle these dots on or off, simply click the eye in the corner
Start Quiz When you feel ready, start the quiz!
//quiz question
Quiz Question When you start a quiz, you can see the questions at the top There are two parts to some quizzes. First, you will need to click on the model that the question is talking about Sometimes, when you click on a dot, a speech bubble appears to show you what the dot is representing. To confirm your selection click on the speech bubble or dot again
//table question
Table Question In the second part of the quiz, you will need to click on the button that answers the question
//inquiry for science
Inquiry Questions After each science lesson, there will be an inquiry question, that will ask for your opinion, or ask you to do a little bit of research Make sure you give reasons for each of your answers! Answering these questions is optional, but answering inquiry questions well can get you extra Dive points each week!
//show ecosystems
Images For some topics, you can learn with interactive pictures and images For some lessons you can swipe to view different pictures, and then click on them to get more information For other lessons, you will need to click on the pictures
//show scientific names
Image Quiz When you start an image quiz, you will need to click on the image that answers the question
//show classification word problems
Word Quiz As you answer more questions correctly, you will then need to click on the right name
//show heat and thermal energy
Molecules To learn about different concepts in chemistry, you can use interactive simulations! Make sure you play around and explore all the controls to see how it affects the system, and learn more!
Start Quiz When you feel ready, start the quiz!

//show rocket
Rocket In this module you can learn about Newtons laws, vectors and gravity! You can choose how to build your rocket, and learn more about physics. The higher your rocket goes, the more you learn!
//show gold ruberg Rube Goldberg Here you can learn about different types of energy, energy transfer, and energy conservation
You can build your own awesome machine, and submit it to the weekly competition, the best machine can be voted for, and the winner will get an award and Dive points! Get creative!
//show waves Waves Here you can learn more about waves, the different types, and their properties You can move the sliders around to better understand what each of these terms mean, and how they are related!
